entry.title: Implementing IAS+AMS with BTP Applications
entry.content:
We're implementing IAS+AMS in which the use of XSUAA is eliminated. The implementation goes like this:

1. CAP application with IAS+AMS (separate app)

2. Generate Client ID and Secret in Cloud Identity Service as AMS uses X509 certificate

3. Add a destination for the CAP application with OAuth2UserTokenExchange authentication and using the Client ID and Secret generated

4. Created a Fiori application with managed App Router connected to CAP application via the destination (separate app)

 

The steps followed are here: 

Deploy and Run the Application on Cloud Foundry

[Blog Series] X.509 certificate-based authentication(mTLS) – Demystified

 

With this setup, is it possible to totally not use XSUAA? If not, can you help me understand what should be the correct way of implementing IAS+AMS including the destination setup?

entry.title: The Ultimate Guide to SAP S/4HANA Batch Management
entry.content:
The Ultimate Guide to SAP S/4HANA Batch Management

Welcome to your complete end-to-end guide on Batch Management in SAP S/4HANA. 🚀 This document is designed for all users—from those new to SAP ("Dummies") to seasoned consultants. We will explore the "what" and "why" behind batch management, provide step-by-step instructions using modern SAP Fiori applications and classic GUI transactions, detail crucial customizing points, and walk through practical exercises.

Chapter 1: Understanding Batch Management

1.1 What is a Batch?

A

batch is a specific quantity of a material that is managed together because it was produced or procured under the same conditions. Think of it like a production run of cookies from the same dough or a shipment of milk arriving with the same expiration date. Each batch is unique and receives its own number, allowing it to be tracked individually throughout the logistics chain.

1.2 Why Use Batch Management?

Batch management is critical for traceability, quality control, and regulatory compliance, especially in industries like pharmaceuticals, food and beverage, and chemicals. Key benefits include:

  • Traceability: Quickly identify which customers received products from a specific batch in case of a recall.
  • Quality Management: Track quality data and inspection results for each specific batch.
  • Shelf-Life Management: Manage materials with expiration dates to ensure strategies like First-Expired, First-Out (FEFO) are used.
  • Specific Stock Handling: Differentiate stock based on characteristics like purity, color, or potency.

Chapter 2: Activating Batch Management

Before you can use batches, you must activate the functionality at several levels.

2.1 Activating at the Client Level

  • Concept: The first step is to enable batch management for the entire system (client). This is a foundational setting.
  • Customizing Point (SPRO):
    • Path: Logistics - General -> Batch Management -> Specify Batch Level and Activate Status Management
    • Action: In this transaction (OMCE), you define whether a batch number should be unique at the material level or at the client level. For robust traceability,

client-level uniqueness is highly recommended. You also activate the batch status management here, which allows a batch to be in a "Restricted" or "Unrestricted" state.

2.2 Activating in the Material Master

  • Concept: Activating batch management at the client level makes it available, but you must explicitly flag each material that will be batch-managed.
  • Why it's important: This gives you the flexibility to manage only the necessary materials in batches, avoiding unnecessary complexity for items that don't require it.
  • SAP Fiori App: Change Material (or transaction MM02)
  • How-To Instructions:
    1. Open the material master record for the item you want to manage in batches.
    2. Navigate to the Purchasing view or the Plant data / stor. 1 view.
    3. Locate the

Batch management checkbox and tick it.

    1. Save the material.
    • Important: You can only set this indicator if the material has no stock. Once set, it cannot be undone if stock exists.

Chapter 3: Batch Classification & Characteristics

This is where the power of Batch Management truly lies. Classification allows you to store specific, detailed data about each batch.

3.1 Creating Characteristics

  • Concept: A characteristic is a field used to describe a batch, such as LOBM_VFDAT (Shelf Life Expiration Date) or a custom characteristic like COLOR or POTENCY.
  • SAP GUI Transaction: CT04
  • How-To Instructions (Example: Creating a Potency Characteristic):
    1. Go to transaction CT04.
    2. Enter a new characteristic name, for example,

Z_POTENCY, and click Create.

    1. On the Basic data tab, provide a Description like "Active Ingredient Potency".
    2. Define the

Data Type as Numeric Format and specify the number of characters and decimal places.

    1. Go to the Values tab and enter the allowed range of values (e.g., from 95.00 to 105.00).
    2. Save the characteristic.

3.2 Creating a Batch Class

  • Concept: A class is a container that groups together all the characteristics relevant for a specific type of material.
  • SAP GUI Transaction: CL02
  • How-To Instructions (Example: Creating a Class for APIs):
    1. Go to transaction CL02.
    2. Enter a new class name, for example, PHARMA_API, and a Class type of 023 (Batch). Click

Create.

    1. On the Basic data tab, enter a Description like "Class for Pharmaceutical APIs".
    2. Go to the Char. tab.
    3. In the characteristic list, add the characteristics you created, such as

Z_POTENCY, and standard characteristics like LOBM_VFDAT (Shelf Life Expiration Date) and LOBM_LFDAT (Delivery Date).

    1. Save the class.

3.3 Assigning the Class to Materials

  • Concept: The final step is to link the batch class to the material master records that should use it.
  • SAP Fiori App: Change Material (or transaction MM02)
  • How-To Instructions:
    1. Open the material master and go to the Classification view.
    2. Assign your newly created class (e.g.,

PHARMA_API) to the material.

    1. Save the material. Now, every time a new batch is created for this material, the system will prompt for values for the characteristics in this class.

Chapter 4: Shelf Life & Expiration Date (SLED) Management

This is a critical function within Batch Management, essential for perishable goods.

4.1 Concept and Calculation

The Shelf Life Expiration Date (SLED), often called the Best Before Date (BBD), is the date until which a material can be used. The system can automatically calculate this date during goods receipt based on two key fields in the material master and the date of production entered by the user.

The formula is simple:

SLED = Date of Production + Total Shelf Life

4.2 Master Data Setup for SLED

  • Concept: To enable automatic SLED calculation and checks, you must maintain specific fields in the material master.
  • SAP Fiori App: Change Material (or transaction MM02)
  • How-To Instructions:
    1. Open the material master for your batch-managed item.
    2. Go to the Plant data / stor. 1 view.
    3. Total shelf life: Enter the total lifespan of the product in days (e.g., 365).
    4. Min. remaining shelf life: Enter the minimum number of days of shelf life the material must have upon receipt to be accepted by your warehouse (e.g., 30). This is crucial for preventing the acceptance of goods that will expire too soon.
    5. Save the material.

4.3 Customizing SLED Checks

  • Concept: You need to tell the system when and how to perform the SLED check. This is done in customizing and is typically configured per plant and movement type.
  • Customizing Point (SPRO):
    • Path: Logistics - General -> Batch Management -> Shelf Life Expiration Date (SLED) -> Set Expiration Date Check
    • Action 1 (Activate per Plant): In this transaction (OMJ5), ensure that the SLED check is active for your plant.
    • Action 2 (Configure per Movement Type): In the same transaction, you can define the system's behavior for a movement type (e.g., 101 - Goods Receipt). The options control whether the date of production is mandatory and if the minimum remaining shelf life check should be performed.

4.4 Process Example: SLED Check at Goods Receipt

When a user posts a goods receipt for a batch-managed material with SLED data maintained:

  1. Transaction: MIGO (Post Goods Movement)
  2. User Input: The user enters the Date of Production on the batch detail screen.
  3. System Calculation: The system automatically calculates the SLED using the formula Date of Production + Total Shelf Life.
  4. System Check: The system then calculates the Remaining Shelf Life (SLED - Today's Date) and compares it to the Min. remaining shelf life from the material master.
  5. Result: If the remaining life is greater than the minimum required, the posting is allowed. If it is less, the system will issue a warning or an error message, preventing the receipt of goods that are close to expiring.

Chapter 5: Batch Determination (Search Strategy)

Batch determination automates the process of finding and selecting the right batches during logistics movements, such as picking for a delivery or staging for a production order.

5.1 Setting up a Search Strategy

  • Concept: A batch search strategy defines the rules the system uses to find and sort batches. A common strategy is

FEFO (First-Expired, First-Out), where the system prioritizes batches that will expire soonest.

  • Why it's important: It automates picking, reduces manual errors, ensures compliance with business rules (like FEFO), and optimizes inventory usage by preventing stock from expiring.
  • SAP Fiori App: Manage Search Strategies - Batch (or transaction VCH1 for Sales, MCH1 for Inventory/Production)
  • How-To Instructions (Example: FEFO Strategy for Sales):
    1. Launch the "Manage Search Strategies - Batch" Fiori app (or go to

VCH1).

    1. Select the Strategy Type for Sales (e.g., SD01).
    2. Create a new strategy for a specific material or a combination of customer and material.
    3. In the strategy details, define the Number of Batch Splits allowed (how many different batches can be used to fulfill one order line).
    4. Click the Sort button. This is the core of the FEFO strategy.
    5. In the sort rule, add the characteristic LOBM_VFDAT (Shelf Life Expiration Date) and set the sort direction to Ascending. This tells the system to sort batches with the earliest expiration date first.
    6. Save the search strategy.

Part 2: The Comprehensive Master Data & Process Test Plan

This section provides practical exercises to configure and test the Batch Management functionality in an end-to-end flow.

Scenario

You are a consultant for a pharmaceutical company. You need to configure batch management for a new Active Pharmaceutical Ingredient (API) that is purchased from an external supplier. The API must be tracked by batch, with strict control over its shelf life, and the company uses a First-Expired, First-Out (FEFO) picking strategy.

Exercise 1: Core Customizing and Master Data Setup

  • Objective: Configure the basic settings and create the necessary characteristics and class for the API.
  • Execution Steps:
    1. Activate Batch Management (SPRO - OMCE): Ensure Batch Level is set to "Unique at Client Level" and Batch Status Management is active.
    2. Create Characteristics (CT04):
      • Create Z_POTENCY (Numeric, e.g., 98.00-102.00%).
      • Create Z_SUPPLIER_BATCH (Character, 20 chars).
    3. Create Class (CL02):
      • Create a class named API_CLASS with Class Type 023.
      • Assign the characteristics Z_POTENCY, Z_SUPPLIER_BATCH, and the standard SAP characteristics LOBM_VFDAT (Shelf Life Expiration Date) and LOBM_HERKL (Country of Origin).
  • Expected Outcome: The foundational classification structure for APIs is created and ready to be assigned to materials.

Exercise 2: Create and Configure the Batch-Managed Material with SLED

  • Objective: Create the material master for the new API, enable it for batch management, and set up shelf-life data.
  • Execution Steps:
    1. Create Material (Fiori App "Create Material" / MM01):
      • Create a new Raw Material (ROH) named API-IBUPROFEN.
      • On the Plant data / stor. 1 view, tick the Batch management checkbox.
      • Enter the Total shelf life in days (e.g., 730 days).
      • Enter the Min. remaining shelf life in days (e.g., 90 days).
    2. Assign Class (Classification View): Assign your API_CLASS to the material.
  • Expected Outcome: The API-IBUPROFEN material is created and requires a batch and SLED data for every movement.

Exercise 3: Test the SLED Check at Goods Receipt

  • Objective: Verify that the system correctly calculates the SLED and enforces the minimum remaining shelf life rule.
  • Execution Steps:
    1. Test Case 1 (Successful Receipt):
      • Post a goods receipt (MIGO, Mvt 101) for API-IBUPROFEN.
      • When prompted for the batch, enter a Date of Production from 10 days ago.
      • Expected Outcome: The system calculates the SLED to be 720 days from today. The goods receipt is posted successfully because the remaining shelf life (720 days) is greater than the minimum required (90 days).
    2. Test Case 2 (Failed Receipt):
      • Attempt to post another goods receipt for the same material.
      • This time, enter a Date of Production from 700 days ago.
      • Expected Outcome: The system calculates the SLED to be 30 days from today. It issues a warning or error message (depending on customizing) because the remaining shelf life (30 days) is less than the minimum required (90 days). The posting should be prevented.

Exercise 4: Create and Test the FEFO Batch Search Strategy

  • Objective: Define and test the automatic batch search strategy to ensure FEFO picking.
  • Prerequisites: You have at least two batches of API-IBUPROFEN in stock with different expiration dates.
  • Execution Steps:
    1. Create Search Strategy (MCH1): Create a strategy for movement type 261 (GI for order) for the material API-IBUPROFEN in your plant.
    2. Define Sort Rule: Add the characteristic LOBM_VFDAT and set the sort to Ascending.
    3. Test the Issue (MIGO):
      • Simulate a goods issue of 20 KG to a production order (Movement Type 261).
      • Enter the material, plant, and quantity.
      • Click the Batch Determination button.
  • Expected Outcome: The system automatically finds and proposes the batch with the earliest expiration date first, successfully demonstrating the FEFO search strategy.

entry.title: Re: How to Handle Cross-Global Account Subscriptions and...
entry.content:
Hi, 
as a partner facing the same pain with customers when providing a multitenant application to them, I can share some of my view points.

1. Cross Global Account Subscriptions:
- The registry (subscription) as well as the service broker (instance creation) technically support cross global account consumption, as long as in the provider and subscriber subaccounts are in the same region. As brokers are using the OSB standard, that is already fully possible cross global accounts. Subscriptions / the registry though is not yet organizationally cross global account supported by SAP. Basically someone needs to set a flag, so your subscription becomes available in the customers market place. As far as I know SAP does not yet have a organizational process for that (I hope to stand corrected on that, or at least in the near future). Technical giving a subaccount of your global account is possible, though inconvenient. The security doubts are technically invalid, as cloud services have to trust each other to work together. As multitenant provider you are e.g. able to read all destinations from subscriber subaccounts - as you need to for connections. If the customer doesn't trust you, they technically should not use the BTP / any SaaS Product that holds sensitive data, as all (excluding custom self deployed apps -> as they are not SaaS) work this way. 

2. Bring your own HANA:
- for your second point, I think tough technically possible it doesnt make any sense from a cloud technology perspective, considering my points from before.

Overall: The missing understanding of customers for how cloud works, really leads to pain and blockers when wanting to provide a multitenant app, this could be significantly reduced if subscriptions could be provided cross global accounts. 

Best regards
Sören

entry.title: Re: Sap Composable Storefront problem getting current use...
entry.content:
Here’s how this works in ASM for Spartacus/Commerce 2011:

Why you’re getting those results

  • userService.getCurrentUser() → returns the logged-in ASM agent (Employee), because that’s technically who owns the session.

  • assistedServiceService.getAsmSession().getEmulatedCustomer() → returning null Means the session has not been bound correctly to an emulated customer at the point you’re checking. In Spartacus, this can also happen because ASM state is kept in the storefront layer, not directly injected into the Commerce session until after login/emulation is confirmed.

  • getAssistedServiceFacade().isAssistedServiceAgentLoggedIn() → returns false in Spartacus context because the storefront session doesn’t hold the agent’s login the same way it does in Accelerator.

How to correctly retrieve the emulated customer

  1. From ASM session (Commerce side)
    When the agent has selected/emulated a customer, the AsmSession should have a non-null customer. Use:

     
    CustomerModel emulatedCustomer = assistedServiceService.getAsmSession().getCustomer();

    (Note: In newer versions, getEmulatedCustomer() was renamed/delegated — check both getCustomer() and getEmulatedCustomer()).

  2. From ASM Facade (Spartacus-aware)
    If you’re integrating through the façade layer, you can use:

     
    CustomerData customerData = assistedServiceFacade.getAsmSession().getEmulatedCustomer();

    But this requires that the ASM session is already bound to a customer (after agent presses “Start Session” in Spartacus ASM UI).

  3. From the session attributes
    Spartacus ASM stores state in the session attribute asm_session. You can read it directly:

     
    AsmSession asmSession = (AsmSession) sessionService.getAttribute(AsmConstants.ASM_SESSION_PARAMETER); CustomerModel customer = asmSession != null ? asmSession.getCustomer() : null;

    This is often the most reliable when troubleshooting.

Things to check

  • Confirm the ASM agent has actually clicked "Start Session" for a customer in the Spartacus ASM UI. Until then, Commerce side won’t have the emulated customer set.

  • Make sure you’re looking at the storefront session, not the backoffice session.

  • Enable debug logging for AssistedServiceService and AsmSession. You’ll see when the emulation state is created.

  • If you’ve customized Spartacus ASM, verify that the ASM state is being propagated to the Commerce OCC layer (via the /assistedservicewebservices endpoints). Without that, the backend won’t know which customer is being emulated.

Here’s a safe little snippet you can drop into your Commerce side code to retrieve the ASM emulated customer if one exists:

 
import de.hybris.platform.assistedserviceservices.constants.AsmConstants; import de.hybris.platform.assistedserviceservices.asm.AsmSession; import de.hybris.platform.core.model.user.CustomerModel; import de.hybris.platform.servicelayer.session.SessionService; import org.springframework.beans.factory.annotation.Autowired; public class AsmCustomerHelper { @Autowired private SessionService sessionService; public CustomerModel getEmulatedCustomer() { AsmSession asmSession = sessionService.getAttribute(AsmConstants.ASM_SESSION_PARAMETER); if (asmSession != null && asmSession.getCustomer() instanceof CustomerModel) { return (CustomerModel) asmSession.getCustomer(); } return null; // No ASM session or no emulated customer yet } }
 

How this works

  • AsmConstants.ASM_SESSION_PARAMETER → "asm_session", where Spartacus/ASM stores session state.

  • If the ASM agent has pressed Start Session in Spartacus, this object will contain the CustomerModel.

  • If not, it returns null, which lets you safely handle both cases.

Important: In Spartacus ASM + Commerce 2011, the emulated customer is only set after session start. Before that, you’ll only see the agent as userService.getCurrentUser().

entry.title: How to create 2 input control filters dependent on each other in story
entry.content:
Kindly help me on below requirement please;

suppose I have 2 Dimensions as shared in below screenshots:

Profitcenter (attribute is Group)

Projectcode ((attribute is Group)

Requirement is I need to apply 2 input control filters on each dim above in my input form in story but Profit center values should be dependent on project code selection ..e.g.. if we select projectcode= PP_SRW then the respective profit center should be seen/ selected only…i.e.. PB_SRW, 0569A00000,0569B00000 (but NOT 0123A00000 as its under PP_XXX attribute of profitcenter which is diff from PB_SRW) and accordingly my table data should be filtered.

I already tried with Dataaction with below script but somehow its not writing value (1*0=0) in form. ALso not sure if this is the correct approach for above requirement .

entry.title: How Does SAP Basis Training Prepare You for Troubleshooting Critical Errors?
entry.content:
Introduction

In today’s enterprise IT landscape, SAP systems are the backbone of business operations. Any disruption in these systems can impact productivity, revenue, and decision making. For IT professionals in India, mastering the ability to troubleshoot critical errors is a highly valuable skill, and structured SAP Basis Training in mumbai is the key to developing it.

This blog explores how SAP Basis training equips learners to identify, analyze, and resolve critical system errors, the practical techniques taught during training, and how this prepares professionals for real world SAP challenges.

Understanding SAP System Errors

SAP systems are complex, consisting of multiple layers including the database, application, and presentation layers. Errors can arise from:

  • Configuration Issues – Incorrect system setups or parameter settings.

  • User Authorization Conflicts – Unauthorized access or role misassignments.

  • Performance Bottlenecks – High CPU or memory usage causing slow system response.

  • Integration Failures – Problems in data flow between modules like FI, CO, MM, or HCM.

  • Transport or Update Errors – Failures during system upgrades, patch installations, or transport requests.

Structured SAP Basis Training in mumbai introduces learners to these scenarios in a controlled environment, ensuring they understand the root causes of common issues.

Core Troubleshooting Skills Taught in SAP Basis Training

SAP Basis Training in mumbai focuses on hands on learning to build proficiency in troubleshooting:

  1. System Monitoring and Analysis
  • Using SAP tools like Solution Manager and ST03 for performance tracking.

  • Interpreting system logs to detect anomalies.

  • Monitoring batch jobs, background processes, and database performance.

  1. Error Identification and Diagnosis
  • Learning to distinguish between configuration, database, or user related errors.

  • Analyzing dump logs, trace files, and performance statistics.

  • Using structured approaches to isolate the root cause efficiently.

  1. Problem Resolution Techniques
  • Correcting configuration errors in SAP profiles, parameters, and clients.

  • Adjusting user authorizations and roles to prevent access related issues.

  • Optimizing system performance by tuning memory, CPU allocation, and database queries.

  • Applying patches and updates safely to fix known bugs.

  1. Backup and Recovery
  • Implementing robust backup strategies to prevent data loss.

  • Restoring systems quickly in case of failures to minimize business impact.

  • Simulating disaster recovery scenarios to practice emergency responses.

Hands On Practice: Key to Troubleshooting Mastery

The complexity of SAP systems means that theory alone is insufficient. Effective troubleshooting requires hands on practice:

  • Simulating real world system errors in sandbox environments.

  • Performing test recoveries and configuration adjustments.

  • Collaborating with peers and trainers to solve problems in practical scenarios.

SAP Basis Training in mumbai emphasizes this hands on approach, allowing learners to gain confidence in managing critical issues safely before entering live production systems.

Real World Examples of Troubleshooting

During training, learners encounter scenarios similar to real life challenges:

  • Resolving failed transport requests between development and production environments.

  • Identifying and correcting performance bottlenecks in a multi client SAP system.

  • Fixing authorization conflicts preventing users from accessing essential modules.

  • Managing system crashes during high transaction periods and restoring normal operations.

These exercises teach learners to remain calm under pressure and apply logical problem solving methods.

Preparing for Advanced Troubleshooting

Beyond the basics, SAP Basis training also prepares learners for complex scenarios:

  • Cross module issue resolution where functional and technical errors intersect.

  • Handling integration problems between SAP and third party applications.

  • Implementing automated monitoring tools to detect potential failures before they escalate.

Structured SAP Basis Training in mumbai ensures learners are equipped with both the knowledge and practical skills needed to tackle advanced troubleshooting tasks.

Importance of Analytical and Soft Skills

Successful troubleshooting in SAP Basis requires more than technical expertise:

  • Analytical Thinking – Quickly interpreting system data and logs to identify root causes.

  • Attention to Detail – Avoiding misconfigurations that could cause further issues.

  • Communication Skills – Explaining technical solutions clearly to functional teams and management.

  • Patience and Persistence – Handling complex errors without rushing to incorrect solutions.

Training programs incorporate exercises that help learners strengthen these essential soft skills.

Career Advantages of Troubleshooting Expertise

Proficiency in troubleshooting critical SAP errors significantly enhances career prospects:

  • SAP Basis Administrator – Ensures smooth system operation and resolves incidents efficiently.

  • Technical Consultant – Provides expert solutions for clients during SAP implementation or upgrades.

  • System Analyst – Monitors and maintains system health proactively.

  • Support Specialist – Handles high priority issues and maintains business continuity.

Employers highly value professionals capable of quickly diagnosing and resolving technical challenges, making troubleshooting expertise a key differentiator.

Continuous Learning for Mastery

SAP systems evolve constantly, and troubleshooting skills must evolve as well:

  • Stay updated on new SAP releases, patches, and S/4HANA features.

  • Learn advanced automation tools for proactive monitoring.

  • Engage in workshops, forums, and online resources to share knowledge and learn from industry experts.

Continuous practice ensures that SAP Basis professionals remain effective and confident in live environments.

   

Troubleshooting critical SAP errors is a complex but highly rewarding skill, essential for IT professionals managing enterprise systems. Structured SAP Basis Training in mumbai provides the theoretical knowledge, hands on practice, and practical exposure needed to tackle real world system issues confidently.

By mastering system monitoring, error diagnosis, problem resolution, and backup recovery, learners are well prepared to handle production SAP systems. Combined with analytical thinking and soft skills, this training empowers professionals to pursue rewarding careers as SAP Basis administrators, consultants, and technical specialists, ensuring they can maintain system integrity and business continuity in any organization.

entry.title: Missing IDATYPE in USR21
entry.content:
Hi SAP Community,

We’re currently using the Fiori app “Manage Teams and Responsibilities” and have encountered an issue when trying to add employees to a team.

The app displays a list of users eligible to be added, and we’ve identified that the key criterion for inclusion is the IDTYPE field in table USR21. Specifically, only users with IDTYPE = 2 or 4 appear in the selection list.

However, we’ve noticed that some users have no IDTYPE set at all (the field is blank in USR21), which means they’re excluded from the app’s selection list.

We’ve already tried assigning a workplace to these users via SU01, hoping that would trigger the IDTYPE to be set to 4 — but unfortunately, it didn’t change anything.

Our question: How can we set or populate the IDTYPE for these users so they become visible in the app?

Thanks in advance!

entry.title: What is planned for the 2511 release of SAP Variant Configuration and Pricing?
entry.content:
The 2511 release of SAP Variant Configuration and Pricing is planned to be deployed to BTP customer tenants on October 22, 2025:

Administration UI and Administration service:

Release

Test/Non-Productive & Productive Upgrades

2511

October 22, 2025

Variant Configuration service & Pricing service:

Release

Test/Non-productive Upgrade

Productive Upgrade

2511

October 22, 2025

November 12, 2025

 

This blog covers the following planned innovations:

  • Configuration and Pricing Services – Root Certificate Change
  • Configuration and Pricing Services – Deprecation of /closeSession
  • Configuration and Pricing Services – Enable traces per request
  • Configuration and Pricing Services – Data center updates for Microsoft Azure in Sydney, Australia
  • Pricing service – Use an external tax provider for U.S. taxes
  • Pricing service – Enhancements to price agreements (stateless pricing only)
  • Variant Configuration service – Read dependency code
  • Variant Configuration service – Analyze the execution of dependencies
  • Administration – Option to improve delta replication performance for pricing

It also includes a call to act regarding the following changes:

  • Configuration and Pricing Services – Root Certificate Change
  • Configuration and Pricing Services – Deprecation of /closeSession

 

Please check the updated roadmap and release notes after the release date to see which of these features were delivered as planned.

 

Disclaimer

The information in this presentation is confidential and proprietary to SAP and may not be disclosed without the permission of SAP.
Except for your obligation to protect confidential information, this presentation is not subject to your license agreement or any other service or subscription agreement with SAP. SAP has no obligation to pursue any course of business outlined in this presentation or any related document, or to develop or release any functionality mentioned therein.

This presentation, or any related document and SAP's strategy and possible future developments, products and or platforms directions and functionality are all subject to change and may be changed by SAP at any time for any reason without notice. The information in this presentation is not a commitment, promise or legal obligation to deliver any material, code or functionality.  This presentation is provided without a warranty of any kind, either express or implied, including but not limited to, the implied warranties of merchantability, fitness for a particular purpose, or non-infringement. This presentation is for informational purposes and may not be incorporated into a contract. SAP assumes no responsibility for errors or omissions in this presentation, except if such damages were caused by SAP’s intentional or gross negligence.

All forward-looking statements are subject to various risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from expectations. Readers are cautioned not to place undue reliance on these forward-looking statements, which speak only as of their dates,
and they should not be relied upon in making purchasing decisions.

 

Configuration and Pricing Services – Root Certificate Change

The root certificates on SAP BTP are planned to be updated in Q1 2026. For more details and the timelines see the SAP Note 3566727. See also SAP BTP Cloud Foundry: switching to higher securit... - SAP Community.

Action: Calls to configuration and pricing services
This is a breaking change for calling the configuration and pricing services. Please verify whether your landscape, from which SAP Variant Configuration and Pricing is called, is already supporting the new root certificate, especially if you are using custom integrations. This is due on the dates mentioned in the SAP Note 3566727.

Action: Data replication with SAP HANA smart data integration (SDI)
On HANA Cloud, a cross-signed certificate which supports the old and new one will be used during a transition period. Please upgrade the SDI DP Agent to version 2.8.0.2 or higher or follow the workaround of the SAP Note 3617329.  
All SAP Enterprise Cloud Services (ECS) / RISE customers have been informed via a top issue. See also the SAP Note 3622538.

 

Configuration and Pricing Services – Deprecation of /closeSession

The endpoints POST /closeSession of the configuration and pricing services used to be used to remove configurations and pricing documents from the HTTP session. This is no longer required because of improved resource management.

The endpoints were set to be deprecated and will be removed with the release 2605.

Action: If called from your application, remove those calls before the May release next year (2026).

More information was published with the 2025 May release in the API definition of the Pricing service and the Variant Configuration service and in the Development Guide (Pre-Production).

 

Configuration and Pricing Services – Enable traces per request

Engine traces and extension traces can be enabled or disabled per tenant. When enabled, all requests to the configuration service or the pricing service for that tenant write traces.

To increase the usability and reduce the number of unnecessary trace files, it is desirable to only enable the traces for a specific user session, but our cloud services do not know about the user or a user session in the calling application, for example in SAP CPQ.

Alternatively, we will enable tracing per request. For that, we will introduce the new setting ON_REQUEST additionally to the existing trace settings ON and OFF, which must be set in the administration UI of the configuration and pricing services.
To determine for what service calls the traces shall be collected, the new header parameter x-cps-trace must be passed for each relevant service call. The relevant trace type must be set as a parameter value:

  • For the pricing service: CONDITION_DETERMINATION, CONDITION_CALCULATION, EXTENSION, or TAXES_US.
  • For the configuration service: CONFIGURATION_ENGINE, EXTENSION, or DEPENDENCY_PROFILING.

Multiple comma-separated values can be set to activate multiple trace categories for the same request.
With that, the calling application can offer functionality to enable traces per user session: If enabled by a user in the application, HTTP requests to the configuration and pricing services should be done for that user with parameter x-cps-trace set.
Note that the traces are only written if the traces have also been enabled using the setting ON_REQUEST in the administration UI:

New: On Request

Not all endpoints of the configuration and pricing services are writing traces. We will add the new header parameter in the API documentation of the relevant endpoints.

More information will be published with the November release in the API Definitions, the  Development Guide (Pre-Production), and the Administration Guide (Pre-Production).

 

Configuration and Pricing Services – Data center updates for Microsoft Azure in Sydney, Australia

Configuration and pricing services are currently available in the following SAP BTP regions:

    • AWS Europe (Frankfurt) (cf-eu10)
    • AWS Europe (Frankfurt) EU Access (cf-eu11)
    • Azure Europe (Netherlands) (cf-eu20)
    • AWS U.S. East (Virgina) (cf-us10)
    • AWS Singapore (cf-ap11)

For new contracts, configuration and pricing services will also be available in Microsoft Azure data center in Australia (Sydney)(cf-ap20).
All configuration and pricing services tenants of a customer must be operated in the same data center. It is not possible to run one tenant on AWS and another on Azure, nor to switch data centers for existing tenants.

 

Pricing service – Use an external tax provider for U.S. taxes

Tax calculation via an external tax provider will be supported for US taxes.

Simple, condition-based tax calculation like MWST is possible with the Pricing service. However, multiple tax levels, tax exemption licenses (for example for Italy, France, and Brazil) are not supported. US tax calculation is not supported, either.

We will take the first steps towards closing those gaps by supporting US tax calculation via an external tax provider analogously to how it is done in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud:

We will use a synchronous outbound SOAP interface, that the pricing engine will call to retrieve the calculated US taxes.

The interface must be implemented by the external tax provider.

The provider’s tax service must be registered with its URL and credentials via SAP Destination service in the customer’s subaccount of the pricing service tenant.
Instead of the service URL, it could also be the URL of an iflow that is used as middleware. Example: Vertex – Calculate Taxes

Destination

The name of the destination is maintained in the administration UI of the pricing service:

Choose the destination

With that, the Pricing service can call the external tax provider.

It does it for the following standard pricing formulas:

Value Formula Number

Description

300

External Tax Call: Line-item tax

301

External Tax Result: Level 1

302

External Tax Result: Level 2

303

External Tax Result: Level 3

304

External Tax Result: Level 4

305

External Tax Result: Level 5

306

External Tax Result: Level 6

500

External Tax Call: Document tax

501

External Tax Call: Document tax

Those formulas are typically assigned to the following condition types for US taxes:

Condition type

Formula number

UTXJ (Tax Jurisdiction Code)

300 (Taxes from External System)

XR1 (Tax Jurisdiction Code Level 1)

301 (Taxes: Value 1)

XR2 (Tax Jurisdiction Code Level 2)

302 (Taxes: Value 2)

XR3 (Tax Jurisdiction Code Level 3)

303 (Taxes: Value 3)

XR4 (Tax Jurisdiction Code Level 4)

304 (Taxes: Value 4)

XR5 (Tax Jurisdiction Code Level 5)

305 (Taxes: Value 5)

XR6 (Tax Jurisdiction Code Level 6)

306 (Taxes: Value 6)

UTXD (US Tax per Document)

500 (collect tax input)

UTXE (US Tax per Document)

501 (get tax output data)

We will document the outbound interface with the exact input and output parameters, including information on where to obtain the data for the input parameters and how to transmit them to the pricing service.

The calls to the external tax provider can be traced as used from engine traces or extension traces:

Tracing external tax calls

Additional license costs may apply for using the external tax provider.

More information will be published with the November release in Supported Standard Pricing Exits (Pre-Production), the Administration Guide (Pre-Production), the Development Guide (Pre-Production) and a new document for tax provider integration.

 

Pricing service – Enhancements to price agreements (stateless pricing only)

priceAgreements input structure allows an application to call the stateless pricing endpoint passing the condition rates that are supposed to be used for price calculation instead of those condition rates that were replicated from the back end. This was introduced in the past for price simulation purposes.

Some enhancements to price agreements in stateless pricing are planned for the upcoming November release:

Price Agreements

Condition supplements, such as related surcharges or discounts, that are linked to a primary condition, can be passed alongside the primary conditions. This ensures that all dependent pricing elements are considered during price simulation.

Example for a condition type PR00 with a supplement condition DISP, both with scales:

{
  "priceAgreements": [
         {
         "conditionTypeId": "PR00",
         "calculationType": "C",
         "rate": {
                 "value": "100.00",
                 "unit": "EUR"
                 },
         "rateQuantity": {
                 "value": 1,
                 "unit": "EA"
                 },
         "scale": {
                 "scaleUnit": "EA",
                 "scaleType": "A",
                 "levels": [
                          {
                           "scaleValue": "1.000",
                           "scaleRate": {
                                   "value": "100.00",
                                   "unit": "EUR"
                          }
                          },
                          {
                            "scaleValue": "2.000",
                            "scaleRate": {
                                   "value": "90.00",
                                   "unit": "EUR"
                                   }
                          },
                          {
                            "scaleValue": "3.000",
                            "scaleRate": {
                                   "value": "85.00",
                                   "unit": "EUR"
                                   }
                          }
                          ]
                 },
                 "supplementConditions": [
                 {
                   "conditionTypeId": "DISP",
                   "calculationType": "A",
                   "rate": {
                          "value": "-5.000",
                          "unit": "P1"
                    },
                   "scale": {
                          "scaleUnit": "EA",
                          "scaleType": "A",
                          "levels": [
                                 {
                                   "scaleValue": "1.000",
                                   "scaleRate": {
                                            "value": "-5.000",
                                            "unit": "P1"
                                            }
                                   },
                                   {
                                    "scaleValue": "2.000",
                                    "scaleRate": {
                                            "value": "-10.000",
                                            "unit": "P1"
                                            }
                                   },
                                   {
                                   "scaleValue": "3.000",
                                   "scaleRate": {
                                            "value": "-15.000",
                                            "unit": "P1"
                                            }
                                   }
                          ]
                 }
         }
     ]
   }
 ]
}

Passing multiple condition records with the same condition type but different validity periods will be supported. The relevant condition record will automatically be selected and applied based on the pricing date, ensuring accurate handling of time-dependent conditions.

Example of two condition records with different validities for condition type PR00:

{
	"priceAgreements": [
		{
			"conditionTypeId": "PR00",
			"calculationType": "C",
			"rate": {
				"value": "100.00",
				"unit": "EUR"
			},
			"rateQuantity": {
				"value": 1,
				"unit": "EA"
			},
			"validity": {
				"startDate": "2024-01-01",
				"endDate": "2025-01-01"
			}
		},
		{
			"conditionTypeId": "PR00",
			"calculationType": "C",
			"rate": {
				"value": "200.00",
				"unit": "EUR"
			},
			"rateQuantity": {
				"value": 1,
				"unit": "EA"
			},
			"validity": {
				"startDate": "2025-01-02",
				"endDate": "2026-01-01"
			}
		}
	]
}

Dynamic scale base types will be supported as part of the pricing input. Consuming applications can specify the scale base type at runtime (e.g., quantity, value, weight, volume). This allows the correct evaluation of scale conditions based on the input during runtime rather than relying only on predefined customizing.

{
	"priceAgreements": [
		{
			"conditionTypeId": "PR00",
			"calculationType": "C",
			"rate": {
				"value": "100.00",
				"unit": "EUR"
			},
			"rateQuantity": {
				"value": 1,
				"unit": "EA"
			},
			"scale": {
				"scaleBaseType": "C",
				"scaleUnit": "EA",
				"scaleType": "A",
				"levels": [
					{
						"scaleValue": "1.000",
						"scaleRate": {
							"value": "100.00",
							"unit": "EUR"
						}
					},
					{
						"scaleValue": "2.000",
						"scaleRate": {
							"value": "90.00",
							"unit": "EUR"
						}
					},
					{
						"scaleValue": "3.000",
						"scaleRate": {
							"value": "85.00",
							"unit": "EUR"
						}
					}
				]
			}
		}
	]
}

More information will be published with the November release in the API Definition and the Development Guide (Pre-Production).

 

Variant Configuration service – Read dependency code

We will introduce a new endpoint GET /knowledgebases/{kbId}/dependencies/{dependencyId} to receive dependency data, such as name, description, explanation, dependency type, and source code.

GET /dependencies

 

GET /dependencies Response Structure

Example response for constraint CPS_BIG_MENU:

GET /knowledgebases/4740/dependencies/CPS_BIG_MENU

{
  "id": "CPS_BIG_MENU",
  "name": "Add a large drink to big menu",
  "type": "8",
  "sourceCode": "OBJECTS:\n \nBurger IS_A (300) CPS_BURGER,\n \ndrink IS_A (300) CPS_SOFTDRINK\n \nCONDITION:\n \nPART_OF (drink, Burger, '0010') AND\nburger.cps_option_m ='L'\n \nRESTRICTIoNs:\n \n \ndrink.cps_size =  'L'\n \nINFERENCES:\ndrink.cps_size\n"
}

The existing endpoint GET /api/v2/knowledgebases/{kbId} will be extended to return the list of dependencies including dependency name, description and type. Only if new $select parameter value dependencies is passed, the list will be returned.

Enhanced GET /knowledgebases

Enhanced Knowledgebases Response

The new API can be used to read the source code of a constraint, procedure, etc. that is during configuration returned as a reason for a conflict. This could be used for support cases or to build a simple why-not feature where for example the code of a failed precondition is displayed.

More information will be published with the November release in the API Definition and in the Development Guide (Pre-Production).

 

Variant Configuration service – Analyze the execution of dependencies

We will introduce a dependency profiler in the form of a profiling trace.

With the dependency profiling trace, it will be possible to measure the runtimes of dependencies likes constraints and procedure to analyze the model performance.

The trace can be enabled in the administration UI of the configuration service either per tenant, or per service request:

Enable Dependency Profiling

For on-request tracing, the header parameter x-cps-trace: DEPENDENCY_PROFILING must be sent when calling the relevant endpoints.

Dependency execution runtimes and counts are recorded and displayed in the administration UI for the configuration service in the section Configuration > Trace > Dependency Profiling Trace:

Dependency Profiling Trace

With that you can check the overall execution time per dependency per request, including the execution count and average execution time.

You can use the search field to filter the trace on configuration id, request id, dependency name, etc.:

Trace with applied filter

The screen table can also be downloaded as CSV file for further analysis.

Dependency profiling will only be available for the native engine of the Variant Configuration service, not when a product model is processed using AVC Forwarding.

More information will be published with the November release in the Administration Guide (Pre-Production) and the Development Guide (Pre-Production).

 

Administration – Option to improve delta replication performance for pricing

A new option will be added to the Connect to SAP Cloud screen for pricing remote sources: Enable Transmit Data in Compact Mode.

New Option

This will improve the speed of the delta replication by a magnitude. But it breaks the referential integrity among the replicated tables. Therefore, it cannot be used for the replication of knowledge bases, and it can only be recommended to those customers that perform pricing changes only with future validity dates!

Only available for data replication using SAP HANA smart data integration (SDI) with an SAP ERP and SAP S/4HANA on-premise or private cloud back end, but not for S/4HANA Public Cloud.

To be able to use that feature, separated remote sources must be enabled for replication of knowledge bases and pricing data:

Two SDI Remote Sources

More information will be published with the November release in the Administration Guide.

 

With that, you have a good overview of what innovations are planned for the August release. Please check the updated roadmap and release notes after the release date to see which of these features were delivered as planned.

entry.title: Re: How Does SAP Basis Training Prepare You for Troublesh...
entry.content:
SAP Basis training is instrumental in preparing professionals to troubleshoot critical errors in SAP systems by providing a strong understanding of SAP architecture, including application servers, databases, and layers, which helps in identifying root causes.

The training also includes hands-on exercises with real-world scenarios, building practical problem-solving skills. Professionals learn to use diagnostic tools such as SM21, ST22, and SM50/SM51 for quick error detection. They are trained in a structured troubleshooting approach, collecting data, analyzing issues, implementing solutions, and documenting fixes systematically. Additionally, the training emphasizes collaboration with cross-functional teams and continuous learning to stay updated, ensuring effective error resolution.

entry.title: Get all Receipts for an Expense Report in a PDF file
entry.content:
Why This Matters:

Many organizations still rely on the deprecated Reports v2 API to retrieve receipts. However, this API will be decommissioned soon, and continuing to use it creates long-term risks and potential disruption to business processes. Migrating to the supported APIs ensures stability, compliance, and scalability.

Solution Overview:

To retrieve all receipts for an Expense Report in a single PDF file, follow these steps using supported APIs:

Report-Level Receipts:

API Endpoints:

Get the Report ID using Reports v3 API:GET /api/v3.0/expense/reports
Download Report-Level Receipts using Image v1 API:GET https://www.concursolutions.com/api/image/v1.0/report/{reportId}

Entry-Level Receipts:

API Endpoints:

Get Expense Entries for the Report using Entries v3 API:GET https://www.concursolutions.com/api/v3.0/expense/entries?reportID={reportID}
Download Entry-Level Receipts using Image v1 API: GET https://www.concursolutions.com/api/image/v1.0/expenseentry/{entryId}

 

Benefits of This Approach:

  • Uses supported APIs (future-proof).
  • Consolidates all receipts for easier audits and compliance checks.
  • Ensures scalability for clients processing large volumes of reports.
  • Avoids disruption from deprecated functionality.

 

Conclusion:

By transitioning from the deprecated Reports v2 API to the supported Reports v3, Entries v3, and Image v1 APIs, clients can reliably retrieve all receipts from an expense report in a single PDF file. This approach not only ensures compliance with SAP Concur’s supported framework but also provides a scalable, future-proof solution for audit, finance, and compliance needs. Implementing this workflow today helps organizations avoid disruptions tomorrow.

Prerequisites

This post will not discuss authentication with Concur Expense.  Please see this post to get an explanation on authentication and application building within Concur Expense.  You will need an application with the following SCOPEs:

  • EXPRPT
  • IMAGE

entry.title: Re: SAP PUBLIC CLOUD ABAP EML Defintion
entry.content:
Hi @JamesG ,

Hope below information is helpful:

1. Identify the Target Business Object and Operation

 

The "Target Type" is the data structure (or a Business Object type) that the operation component is designed to manipulate or retrieve.

  • Determine the Operation's Purpose: What is the operation component supposed to do? (e.g., CreateSalesOrder, ChangeCustomer, GetMaterialDetails).

  • Identify the Business Object (BO): The BO is the real-world entity the operation acts upon (e.g., SalesOrder, Customer, Material).

 

2. Determine the Target Type from the Target System's Interface

 

The "Target Type" will be the structured data type—often a BAPI structure or an OData Entity Type—that represents the business object on the back-end system (like SAP S/4HANA or SAP ECC).

ScenarioTarget Type SourceWhere to Check
Connecting to SAP ECC/S/4HANA (using BAPIs/RFCs)BAPI Structure/Interface TypeUse transaction SWO1 (Business Object Builder) or SE37 (Function Builder) in the back-end SAP system to find the exact structure used for the Import, Export, and Table parameters of the corresponding BAPI/RFC function module.
Connecting to an OData Service (SAP Fiori/CDS View based)OData Entity TypeCheck the OData service's $metadata document. The Target Type is the specific Entity Type (e.g., SalesOrderType, C_SalesOrderTP) that the BOI operation maps to.
Connecting to a Custom BTP Application (CAP/RAP)Service Entity/StructureThe Target Type is the entity or structure defined in the Core Data Services (CDS) model of the application (e.g., com.sap.internal.bo.SalesOrder).

entry.title: Seeing Skills Before They Matter: People Intelligence in SAP SuccessFactors
entry.content:
Seeing Skills Before They Matter: People Intelligence in SAP SuccessFactors

In HR, we’ve always had a knack for reporting the past — headcount, attrition, training hours, compensation trends. But what if we could flip the script and start looking ahead? What if we could see the skills that will matter tomorrow, and act on them today?

That’s exactly what People Intelligence in SAP Business Data Cloud is helping us do — and it’s something I believe every HR leader should be paying attention to.

The Challenge: Too Much Data, Too Little Insight

Let’s face it — most of us aren’t short on data. We’re drowning in it. The real issue is that it’s scattered across systems: recruiting, learning, payroll, performance, time tracking. Each one tells part of the story, but none give us the full picture.

So when we’re asked questions like:

  • “What skills will we need in 12 months?”
  • “Are we training people in the right areas?”
  • “Do we have the right talent mix for our growth plans?”

we often end up guessing, or reacting too late.

What’s Different with People Intelligence in SAP SuccessFactors?

This is where SAP SuccessFactors integrated with Business Data Cloud really changes the game. It brings together all your HR data — securely and intelligently — and turns it into forward-looking insights.

Here’s what stood out to me:

  • Connected, Trusted HR Data

People Intelligence automatically harmonizes data from across SAP SuccessFactors — Employee Central, Learning, Recruiting, Compensation, and more. No more spreadsheets. No more silos.

  • Predictive Insights with SAP Business AI

It’s not just about dashboards. You can ask questions like:

  • “Which skills are trending upward in our engineering teams?”
  • “If we expand in Southeast Asia, do we have the right talent mix?”

The system uses AI to surface risks, model scenarios, and suggest actions — before problems arise.

  • Natural Language with Joule

This is a game-changer. Instead of building reports, you just ask:
“Do we have enough cybersecurity talent in EMEA?”
Joule understands the context, pulls the data, and gives you a clear, actionable answer.

  • Cross-Functional Alignment

Finance, operations, and HR can now work off the same data foundation. That means workforce planning is finally aligned with business strategy — not an afterthought.

Real Business Impact

This isn’t just about better analytics. It’s about better outcomes:

  • Spot skill gaps before they slow down the business
  • Reduce emergency hiring costs
  • Align learning investments with future needs
  • Elevate HR’s role in strategic planning

A Few Real-World Scenarios

  • A tech company sees demand for AI/ML skills doubling. They launch upskilling programs now — not when it’s too late.
  • A manufacturing firm plans a new plant. People Intelligence helps them confirm contractor availability in the region — avoiding delays.
  • A consulting firm simulates growth models and sees how skill availability affects project timelines — before committing.

My Take

People Intelligence isn’t just another HR tool. It’s a mindset shift — from reactive to predictive, from fragmented to unified. It gives HR leaders the visibility and confidence to act before skills gaps become business risks.

If you’re using SAP SuccessFactors, this is something you should explore. It’s not just about data — it’s about decisions.

Learn more about People Intelligence in SAP Business Data Cloud

Over to you:
What skills do you think will be most critical for your organization in the next 1–2 years? Let’s start a conversation.

entry.title: Re: ME23N Display Purchase Order: Output is blank
entry.content:
Some of the reasons why NEU still fails when you manually add it in ME22N

  • Incomplete key fields: When you add NEU, you must also fill medium, partner function, and language. If any are missing or inconsistent with vendor master data, the record won’t be saved to NAST.
  • Output determination procedure not assigned: Check in customizing (SPRO → MM → Purchasing → Messages → Output Control → Message Determination Schemas → Assign Schema to Document Type). If the PO’s document type doesn’t have a schema with NEU, the system won’t accept it.
  • Condition record missing: Even if you add NEU manually, the system may reject it if no valid condition record exists (transaction MN04 for NEU). That’s why new POs work (condition records fixed) but old ones don’t.
  • Change message indicator: For existing POs, if the “message determination” indicator isn’t set (e.g. no change flagged), the system won’t trigger output.
  • NAST update blocked: If the PO was created before config was corrected, the system never wrote a NAST entry. Adding NEU now may not work unless you also trigger a change that re‑evaluates output.

entry.title: Best Practices for Pay Transparency in SuccessFactors Recruiting
entry.content:
Show me the money!

It’s not just candidates asking anymore, though, now it’s the law.

More and more often, employers are being required to share pay information with prospective candidates when posting job opportunities.  Many have chosen to post this information even when it’s not mandatory.  However, different locations have different requirements about what must be posted.  So how should you configure your SuccessFactors instance to be compliant with pay transparency laws?

I’m going to outline the steps to take to properly configure SuccessFactors Recruiting for pay transparency.  First, though, we need to make a few assumptions:

  • The employer has pay ranges in their job architecture for each job.
  • The employer is using SuccessFactors Recruiting Management, Recruiting Marketing, and Employee Central with Position Management.
  • The employer wishes to allow recruiters to edit the pay information that is posted on requisitions, to accommodate for things such as union requirements or localization.

Step 1:  Define Posting Range Fields on Requisition

The standard minimum and maximum pay fields need to be defined on the requisition, so they can be auto-populated with data from the job architecture.  The pay range fields that are posted need to be text fields, so they can be mapped to Recruiting Marketing properly.  Because these posting fields are only used for Recruiting purposes, they don’t belong in the job architecture.  They should be populated on a requisition and used only for that requisition.

You can do this configuration in Admin Center>Manage Templates or via Provisioning, using an xml editor:

Don’t forget to permission the fields.  Typically, the standard minimum and maximum pay fields are read-only, as they will be auto-populated.  The posting range fields are editable so the recruiting operator can edit them or add context.  If you don’t wish to allow editing, you could set business rules to auto-populate them, and even hide them from the user.  You might also want to update other settings, such as making these fields reportable.

 Step 2:  Set Business Rules to Populate Pay Ranges

Set up the business rule to map position data to the requisition, including the salaryMin and salaryMax fields.  You may also want to include other fields like salaryMid or paygrade.

Admin Center>Configure Business Rules

Once populated, this is how the fields will look on a requisition:

When populating these fields, keep your end goal in mind.  If your jobs will be reposted on job boards that require only an amount in these fields, don’t add additional comments within the fields.

Step 3:  Map Posting Fields to Recruitment Marketing

The fields from the requisition need to be mapped to Recruiting Marketing so they can be posted.  Each needs to be in a discrete field so job boards can properly use this data.  If you are concerned about using the limited custom fields available, you can also repurpose standard fields for mapping.

Step 5:  Relabel Recruitment Marketing Fields

In Recruiting Marketing, you’ll need to update translations so the fields you created have the correct labels.  Find the standard fields you mapped in Step 4 and update the labels to match the fields as defined on the requisition.

Career Site Builder>Tools>Translations

Step 6:  Add Posting Fields to Job Layouts

Add the fields to your job layout in Recruiting Marketing.  This will allow the job posting to display these fields discreetly, rather than including them in the text of the job description.

Career Site Builder>Layouts>Job

When the job is posted, these fields will be available for candidates to see, and will also be available if posting partners scrape your site.

Step 7:  Include Posting Fields in XML Feeds

If your job postings are being distributed to job boards via xml feed, confirm with the vendor if changes are needed to make sure these pay range fields can be received and used on those third-party postings.  The vendor should be able to tell you the layout that needs to be used.  If changes are needed, you will have to work with an implementation partner or support to update your job feeds.

As pay transparency is becoming part of our everyday, the details are still shifting.  Some places now require you to provide information on available benefits or other compensation.  Some places have different requirements for different sizes of employers.  Many of the laws are still being ironed out and requirements are changing frequently.  Make sure you check with your legal or compliance advisors to ensure you are meeting all the requirements wherever you post job opportunities.

While the necessity of posting pay information has been a big shift in mentality for many employers, studies have shown that candidates are more apt not to apply for positions that don’t meet their needs, thereby reducing the number of candidates recruiters need to screen.  It also offers employers an opportunity to differentiate themselves in other ways, such as company culture and future growth.  The underlying intention is to make this playing field fair for everyone involved, giving us all the information we need to make good decisions.

If you need help meeting these requirements or if you are unsure about what you might need to do, please reach out to us!

entry.title: Re: I'm not getting the same result with my FI-GL validat...
entry.content:
Please note in OB28 validations/substitutions are tied to call points in FI (document header, line item, complete document). In classic transactions (FB01, FB50, F‑02, etc.), the system fills BKPF-TCODE with the actual SAP GUI transaction code. Your validation can check BKPF-TCODE = 'FB01' and it works. In Fiori apps like F0718, the posting is not executed under “FB01” at all. Instead, the app calls the Journal Entry API (BAPI_ACC_DOCUMENT_POST / ACC_DOCUMENT) in the background. That means BKPF-TCODE is not populated with FB01. Often it is blank, or filled with a generic technical value. As a result, any validation logic that depends on BKPF-TCODE or “user account” fields behaves differently. This is why you see your validation trigger in FB01 but not in F0718 — it’s normal in S/4HANA.

To fix it, avoid relying on BKPF-TCODE. Instead, use document type, account type, or enrich the posting with a BAdI if you need to distinguish Fiori vs. GUI.

entry.title: Homogeneous Update and Copy to SAP Cloud using RISE with SAP System Transition Workbench
entry.content:
Introduction

In today’s rapidly evolving SAP landscape, customers are increasingly looking for seamless ways to upgrade and migrate their systems to leverage the full potential of SAP S/4HANA and the cloud. As part of the Early Adopter Program, I had the opportunity to work hands-on with the Transition Workbench tool to perform an upgrade from SAP S/4HANA 1909 to SAP S/4HANA 2023 FP03 and subsequently execute a migration to SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud Edition (RISE with SAP).

In this blog, I share my real-world experience from this project — detailing the Update and Tenant Copy methods in SAP BTP Cloud Cockpit, how the Transition Workbench helped streamline the process, and the step-by-step approach I followed to carry out the upgrade and migration successfully. This write-up is designed to help consultants and customers alike understand the practical aspects, challenges, and best practices of such transformations.

I would like to take a moment to recognize and sincerely appreciate the efforts and valuable technical advisory of Ravikiran Chikati, Bharathwaj, Arvind, Srivastava, Piyush and Klumpp, Fabian.  

Overview: Update and Copy to SAP Cloud Cockpit

This process describes how an on-premises SAP S/4HANA or SAP Business Suite (SOH) system is upgraded and replicated to the SAP S/4HANA Cloud, private edition environment using the Transition Workbench and the Update & Copy to Cloud Cockpit approach.

The workflow begins with provisioning a skeleton target system and a migration server in the SAP Cloud environment (steps 1 & 2). The Transition Workbench acts as an intermediate layer to streamline preparation, replication, and upgrade tasks (steps 3–5).

On the source side, preparation steps are executed, the SUM tool performs the in-place upgrade, and the download directories are copied between the migration server and the source system (steps 4, 6, 7 & 8).

After ramp-down activities (step 9), the upgrade is completed, and the system is switched back to the main instance (steps 10 & 12). Finally, ECS post-processing ensures that the migrated and upgraded system is ready for productive use (step 13).

This phased approach—covering Pre-Requisite Checks, Software Download, Preparation, Replication, Downtime Finalization, and Post-Processing—helps customers move from an on-premises S/4HANA or SOH system to SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud Edition (RISE with SAP) efficiently and with minimal risk.

Pre-requisite

Provision/Validation of DNS names in RISE environment

Preparatory actions to be performed by ECS

  1. Provision the Migration VM and the Target System

You will receive the Migration VM details together with the handover of the target landscape details.​

Cockpit-Independent Preparatory Actions

Preparation activities required both from ECS and users to access and work with the "system transition workbench"

Preparatory actions to be performed by ECS

The "RISE with SAP system transition workbench" ("system transition workbench") is installed by ECS on a so-called Migration VM. After preparing the Migration VM, ECS hands it over to the migration partner.

Early Adopter program, are not provided by default on the Migration VM

Preparatory actions to be performed by Users

  • The workbench requires access to internet, preconfigured by the user's proxy.
  • Remote Function Call (RFC)
  • RFC requests are used for the communication to the application servers.

Migration VM must have connection to the source system to make RFC calls.

the following source system parameters are required:

  • DDIC user in client 000 of the source system
  • Instance host
  • Domain
  • Instance number

Access to Services and Tools

  • The "system transition workbench" needs to access to the following:
  • The source system and the target SAP HANA database using SQL
  • The Maintenance Planner
  • The analytics service
  • The Software Download Service (SDS)

General Network Requirements

The "system transition workbench" has the following network requirements on the Migration VM:

  • Connection to source and target database using SQL ports
  • Connection to the source application server using remote function call (RFC)
  • Connection to the Maintenance Planner, SAP download services, CRLbag service, and analytics tools

Requirement for Maintenance Planner and HANA Replication

  • The source system must be known to the Maintenance Planner
  • Users must manually create a transaction in the Maintenance Planner
  • Validate all HANA Replication related parameters are applied on source and target database (Refer Pre-req sheet)
  • Validate if Log mode of Source to be Normal and keep monitoring log volume size to store logs to be replicated.
  • Validate if

a) Auto failover should be disabled.

b) Disable Database Hooks: Hooks are HA/DR providers which sends information to initiate auto failover. These can be disabled from global.ini file.

  • Validate if nameserver Service ports needs to be opened in Source System and target system, Range: 3<inst_id><service port> or 3<inst_id>XX. Telnet test can be performed to validated if ports are open

Created the ticket to enable the Migration VM from ECS. You will receive the mail after enabling the Migration VM from ECS. TWB tool has been installed on the migration server. Make sure you are on the latest Version before starting the project 

RISE with SAP System Transition Workbench Version: 0.36.1

SAP System Transition Workbench
Once Enabled the Transition Workbench login to VDI or Citrix of customer access the Below URL

Note: LT1 Migration VM is meant for customer it can be accessed from the Customer Network only

https://<hostname>. <domain_name>:1129/lmsl/slocon/docs/index.html 

Login with user sapadm, if password not available reset at the OS level to get the password.

Create the Vault to secure the password storage, a KeePass Vault is to be created.       It will be encrypted with the vault password you enter.

 Start the Uptime Phase

Uptime Phase has 3 Steps

  1. Pre-requisite Checks
  2. Download
  3. Preparation and Replication

Pre-requisites Checks

Start the Task 1.1: Pre-requisite Checks for Homogenous Conversion to SAP S/4 HANA

Below are the Parameter which needed for Tenant Copy

Source System

Target System

Confirm the setting can be applied to the target database of the productive system

Clear the result with error

Perform the backup of the Source and Target Database within the last 24 hours

Uninstall the LCAPPS and AFL components from the source database as it is not installed on the Target Database

Apply the SAP Note 3409764 in the Source System

Confirm the SAP Note has been applied on the Source System and proceed further

Software Download

Start the Task 2.1: Software Download

Preparation and Replication

Start the Task 3.1: Pre-requisite for Homogeneous Conversion to SAP S/4 HANA

Start the Task 3.2: Initialize and Monitor SAP HANA Replication

Execute the below SQL Statement to check the Replication Status

SELECT DATABASE_NAME, SOURCE_HOST, TARGET_HOST, REPLICATION_STATUS, REPLICATION_STATUS_DETAILS, LAST_LOG_POSITION, LAST_LOG_POSITION_TIME, SHIPPED_LOG_POSITION, SHIPPED_LOG_POSITION_TIME from SYS_DATABASES.M_DATABASE_REPLICA_STATISTICS

Once Replication Status in ACTIVE Status

Copy the Downloaded Directory from LT1 (Migration VM) to Source System

Copy the addons into this Download Directory

Start the SUM on the Source System

SUM Uptime Activities

cd /usr/sap/SID/Cycle2/SUM/abap/

./SUMSTART confighostagent SID

Extraction

SUM URL - https://<hostname>.<domainname>:1129/lmsl/sumabap/SID/slui

Configuration Phase

Checks Phase

Prep-processing Phase

Ramp-down Activities Before downtime

Execution Phase

Post Processing After Downtime

Finalize Replication Steps

Start the Downtime Phase in this phase you have two steps

  1. Finalize
  2. Post-Processing

Start the Task 1.1: Finalize Tenant Replication for Homogeneous Conversion to SAP HANA

Start the Task 2.1: Post-Processing

Confirm and proceed further to complete the Transition workbench

Perform the Post Activities

Execute the Report SHDB_MIGRATION_CHECK

Manual Post Processing

Create the SR Ticket to Switch Application back to Main instance after the Migration

Update hdbuserstore and Check R3trans -d / -x (Validate connection to DB is working on all APPS)

Updated as part of the Switch Main Instance SR

Perform the Post Activities

Silent Data Migration

Go to transaction SDM_MON -> Current Client Info

Run SJOBREPO -> SAP_SDM_EXECUTOR_POSTPROCESSING

Handover to ECS Post Processing

Summary

The RISE with SAP System Transition Workbench is not just a tool - it's your navigation system in the digital transformation landscape. By radically reducing manual efforts, minimizing errors, and streamlining processes, it ensures that your journey to the private cloud is as smooth and efficient as possible. Check out our documentation and early adaptor program and discover how you can leverage this incredible innovation to facilitate your migration endeavors.
